query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 La molta gente e le diverse piaghe 2 avean le luci mie sì inebrïate, 3 che de lo stare a piangere eran vaghe.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The great crowd and the various wounds 2 had so intoxicated my eyes 3 that they were eager to stand and weep.
**Cornish:**
1 An bobel vras ha’n gwella dowr divers 2 o dueth vy’m golwg mor wynn, 3 byttegens o sevel o veuons ow weth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
4 Ma Virgilio mi disse: «Che pur guate? 5 perché la vista tua pur si soffolge 6 là giù tra l’ombre triste smozzicate?
7 Tu non hai fatto sì a l’altre bolge; 8 pensa, se tu annoverar le credi, 9 che miglia ventidue la valle volge.
query.result:
**English:**
4 But Virgil said to me: “What are you just staring at? 5 Why does your gaze linger so much 6 down there among the sad, mutilated shades?
7 You have not done so in the other ditches; 8 think, if you believe you can count them, 9 that the valley goes around for twenty-two miles.
**Cornish:**
4 Mes Virgili a leveris: “Pyth owth omma gwel? 5 Rag owth owth golwg ow soffolga kemmys 6 allá bys ynter an scouthow trist smozzicate?
7 Ty ny wruthylla kepar henna y’n bolgeow erel; 8 meury, po ty a grys y konta, 9 an dowr a drovia moy es y vownsi mildir.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 E già la luna è sotto i nostri piedi; 11 lo tempo è poco omai che n’è concesso, 12 e altro è da veder che tu non vedi».
query.result:
**English:**
10 And already the moon is beneath our feet; 11 the time is now short that is granted to us, 12 and there is more to see that you do not see.
**Cornish:**
10 Ha lemmyn an loor yw bys y’n treus; 11 An eur yw byghan lemmyn owth omma ros, 12 ha moy yw dhe weles na’th owth gweles.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 «Se tu avessi», rispuos’ io appresso, 14 «atteso a la cagion per ch’io guardava, 15 forse m’avresti ancor lo star dimesso».
query.result:
**English:**
13 "If you had," I answered him then, 14 "paid attention to the reason why I was looking, 15 perhaps you would have already let me go."
**Cornish:**
13 "Mar tus o ve", me a leveris wosa, 14 "selvys dhe'n keus a welyn, 15 mar pleg vyth dhe'th leveris dhe'n gwell."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Parte sen giva, e io retro li andava, 17 lo duca, già faccendo la risposta, 18 e soggiugnendo: «Dentro a quella cava
19 dov’ io tenea or li occhi sì a posta, 20 credo ch’un spirto del mio sangue pianga 21 la colpa che là giù cotanto costa».
query.result:
**English:**
16 He set off walking, and I followed behind him, 17 the guide, already making his reply, 18 and adding: "Inside that hollow
19 where I was just keeping my eyes so fixed, 20 I believe a spirit of my own blood weeps 21 for the sin that costs so much down there."
**Cornish:**
16 Ev a leveris, ha henna me a sewya, 17 an dyghow, ow tos owth leverel, 18 ha leverel ow tos: "Y'n-dann an dowr
19 lemmyn o wrug ow selwel dhe sel, 20 me a grys owth onen sperys a'm wruk 21 rag an pegh a wra dhe'n bys vyth kost."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Tu eri allor sì del tutto impedito 29 sovra colui che già tenne Altaforte, 30 che non guardasti in là, sì fu partito».
query.result:
**English:**
28 You were then so completely focused 29 on the one who once held Altaforte, 30 that you did not look over there, so he departed."
**Cornish:**
28 Tus o vea wosa owth lettya oll 29 warbarth henna a veu Altaforte, 30 na'th welas ow ena, wosa ow partia."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 «O duca mio, la vïolenta morte 32 che non li è vendicata ancor», diss’ io, 33 «per alcun che de l’onta sia consorte,
34 fece lui disdegnoso; ond’ el sen gio 35 sanza parlarmi, sì com’ ïo estimo: 36 e in ciò m’ha el fatto a sé più pio».
query.result:
**English:**
31 "O my guide, the violent death 32 that has not yet been avenged," I said, 33 "by anyone who shares the shame,
34 made him disdainful; therefore he went away 35 without speaking to me, as I believe: 36 and in this he has made me feel more pity for him."
**Cornish:**
31 "O'm dyghow, an marow vyth kreula 32 na veu venjea bythkweth," me a leveris, 33 "gans neb owth rann an wonta,
34 a wra ow disdeynus; rag henna a wra 35 heb leverel dhym, kepar ha me a grys: 36 ha'n tra wra ow gwres ow moy pyth vyth pio."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Così parlammo infino al loco primo 38 che de lo scoglio l’altra valle mostra, 39 se più lume vi fosse, tutto ad imo.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Thus we spoke until we reached the first place 38 from which the cliff shows the other valley, 39 if there were more light, all the way to the bottom.
**Cornish:**
37 Kepar henna ni a leveris bys dhe'n le duyja 38 lemmyn an garrek a wra'th an dowr aral 39 ow vea moy golow, oll dhe'n bys dhe'n nessa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Quando noi fummo sor l’ultima chiostra 41 di Malebolge, sì che i suoi conversi 42 potean parere a la veduta nostra,
43 lamenti saettaron me diversi, 44 che di pietà ferrati avean li strali; 45 ond’ io li orecchi con le man copersi.
query.result:
**English:**
40 When we were above the last cloister 41 of Malebolge, so that its inhabitants 42 could appear to our sight,
43 various lamentations pierced me, 44 whose arrows were barbed with pity; 45 so I covered my ears with my hands.
**Cornish:**
40 Pandra vea ni o vea warbarth an nessa 41 avel Malebolge, kepar y'n conversys 42 a alla ow tos owth gweles dhe'n golwg ni,
43 lamentys a wra'th ow saetha dhym, 44 owth o stralys o vea ferrys gans pytas; 45 rag henna me a wra'th ow tos ow koverel 46 dhym dyskyn gans ow dewes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Qual dolor fora, se de li spedali 47 di Valdichiana tra ’l luglio e ’l settembre 48 e di Maremma e di Sardigna i mali
49 fossero in una fossa tutti ’nsembre, 50 tal era quivi, e tal puzzo n’usciva 51 qual suol venir de le marcite membre.
query.result:
**English:**
46 What suffering it would be if from the hospitals 47 of Valdichiana between July and September 48 and from Maremma and Sardinia all the sicknesses
49 were all together in one pit, 50 such was it there, and such a stench came from it 51 as is wont to come from rotting limbs.
**Cornish:**
46 Pyth poen a vea, mar owth an spetals 47 a Valdichiana ynter an Gortheren ha'n Metheven 48 ha Maremma ha Sardigna an cleves
49 o vea oll yn-dann onen fos, 50 kepar henna o vea ena, ha kepar poos 51 a wra ow tos ow tevi a'n esel marow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Noi discendemmo in su l’ultima riva 53 del lungo scoglio, pur da man sinistra; 54 e allor fu la mia vista più viva
55 giù ver’ lo fondo, la ’ve la ministra 56 de l’alto Sire infallibil giustizia 57 punisce i falsador che qui registra.
query.result:
**English:**
52 We descended onto the last bank 53 of the long cliff, still on the left; 54 and then my sight was keener
55 down towards the bottom, where the minister 56 of the high Lord's infallible justice 57 punishes the falsifiers that she registers here.
**Cornish:**
52 Ny discendens yn-mes an diwetriva 53 a'n scogly hir, mes orth a'n clew-hes, 54 ha'n-na veu gwelow gwell
55 a-woles an-nank, le maystres 56 a'n Arluth ughel, gwirvos justijs 57 a-benys an falsoryon a-scryf hi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Non credo ch’a veder maggior tristizia 59 fosse in Egina il popol tutto infermo, 60 quando fu l’aere sì pien di malizia,
61 che li animali, infino al picciol vermo, 62 cascaron tutti, e poi le genti antiche, 63 secondo che i poeti hanno per fermo,
64 si ristorar di seme di formiche; 65 ch’era a veder per quella oscura valle 66 languir li spirti per diverse biche.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I do not believe that greater sadness could be seen 59 in Aegina, with all its people sick, 60 when the air was so full of malice,
61 that the animals, down to the tiniest worm, 62 all perished, and then the ancient people, 63 as the poets firmly believe,
64 were restored from a seed of ants; 65 for it was a sight to see in that dark valley 66 the spirits languishing in various heaps.
**Cornish:**
58 Ny credaf vyth bythqueth moy tryst bras 59 yn Egina, an bobel oll cleves, 60 pan veu an eyr leun avel drogyans,
61 bythqueth an eneval, bys dhe'n byghan gwymp, 62 a-dhyskynnas oll, ha'n-na hen dus, 63 avel henna's gweles an bardhys,
64 a-dhallethas a-hedhy formigas; 65 rag o weles y'n-na dowr-gwyn val 66 an sperys a-dholaf y'n-dann dhe biche dyffrans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Qual sovra ’l ventre e qual sovra le spalle 68 l’un de l’altro giacea, e qual carpone 69 si trasmutava per lo tristo calle.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Some lay belly down, others on their backs, 68 one on top of the other, and some crawled 69 along the sorry path.
**Cornish:**
67 Yn nevra war an golon ha war an dhewlyn 68 An eyl a-ugh yn eyl, ha nevra a-grymmys 69 A-droppya dre wosa an fordh trist.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Passo passo andavam sanza sermone, 71 guardando e ascoltando li ammalati, 72 che non potean levar le lor persone.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Step by step we went, without speaking, 71 watching and listening to the sick, 72 who could not lift themselves up.
**Cornish:**
70 Pass ha pass a-droppyn ni a-leveris, 71 A-sel ha golcowgh an cleves, 72 Nebes ollas sevel aga personow.

**English:**
73 I saw two sitting, leaning against each other, 74 as dish is leaned against dish to warm them, 75 from head to foot smeared with scabs;
76 and I never saw a groom curry a horse 77 that was waiting for its master, 78 or one who was loath to stay awake,
79 as each of these furiously bit himself 80 with his nails because of the great rage 81 of the itching, for which there is no relief;
82 and they tore at the scabs with their nails, 83 as a knife scrapes scales from a bream 84 or some other fish that has larger scales.
**Cornish:**
73 Me a welas dew sedhes ow tos, 74 Dell yw tos ow tos dhe welshe, 75 A-dhia an ben dhe’n tres, ow tos.
76 Ha ny welas vy nyns yw tos ow tos, 77 Ragas ow tos ow tos dhe’n argluydh, 78 Neb dhe’n neb nyns yw tos ow tos.
79 Dell pub onan a-leveris ow tos, 80 An eyl war eyl dhe’n kres an feth, 81 A-wul dhe’n kres, nyns yw socour moy.
82 Ha dell onan a-leveris an scav, 83 Dell cotyla ow tos an scayl a-ugh pysg, 84 Neb pysg aral a-ugh moy scayl.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 «O tu che con le dita ti dismaglie», 86 cominciò ’l duca mio a l’un di loro, 87 «e che fai d’esse talvolta tanaglie,
88 dinne s’alcun Latino è tra costoro 89 che son quinc’ entro, se l’unghia ti basti 90 etternalmente a cotesto lavoro».
query.result:
**English:**
85 “O you who are tearing yourself apart with your fingers,” 86 my leader began to say to one of them, 87 “and who sometimes make pincers of them,
88 tell me if there is any Latin among these 89 who are here, if your nails are enough 90 to do this work forever.”
**Cornish:**
85 “O ty ow tos ow tos gans dha dhewdh,” 86 A-leveris an dywgh dhe’n eyl a-ugh anedha, 87 “Ha ow tos ow tos gans dha dhewdh,
88 Dywh vy yw Latino ynter anedha 89 Neb yw ena, pub vy yw dhewdh, 90 Ha bos dhe leverel an gweyth ma.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 «Latin siam noi, che tu vedi sì guasti 92 qui ambedue», rispuose l’un piangendo; 93 «ma tu chi se’ che di noi dimandasti?».
query.result:
**English:**
91 “We are Latins, as you see us so wasted 92 here, both of us,” replied one, weeping; 93 “but who are you who ask about us?”
**Cornish:**
91 “Latinos yw ni, dell gwels ty ni vel drogys 92 Ena oll an dhew, a-leveris an eyl ow weli; 93 Mes ty, pyw yw ty, ow tos ow tos a-houlis?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 E ’l duca disse: «I’ son un che discendo 95 con questo vivo giù di balzo in balzo, 96 e di mostrar lo ’nferno a lui intendo».
query.result:
**English:**
94 And the leader said: “I am one who descends 95 with this living man from crag to crag, 96 and I intend to show him Hell.”
**Cornish:**
94 Ha’n dywgh a-leveris: “My yw unn ow tos ow tos 95 Gans an byw ena a-ugh bal a-ugh bal, 96 Ha dhe woles an Ifarn dhe’n neb ena.”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Allor si ruppe lo comun rincalzo; 98 e tremando ciascuno a me si volse 99 con altri che l’udiron di rimbalzo.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Then the general cry broke off; 98 and each one, trembling, turned to me 99 with others who had heard him by ricochet.
**Cornish:**
97 Anedha a-leveris an comun rincalz; 98 Ha oll ow tos ow tos a-leveris dhe’n vy 99 Gans aral a-ugh anedha a-leveris an rimbalz.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Lo buon maestro a me tutto s’accolse, 101 dicendo: «Dì a lor ciò che tu vuoli»; 102 e io incominciai, poscia ch’ei volse:
103 «Se la vostra memoria non s’imboli 104 nel primo mondo da l’umane menti, 105 ma s’ella viva sotto molti soli,
106 ditemi chi voi siete e di che genti; 107 la vostra sconcia e fastidiosa pena 108 di palesarvi a me non vi spaventi».
query.result:
**English:**
100 The good master drew close to me, 101 saying: "Tell them what you wish"; 102 and I began, after he had turned:
103 "If your memory is not stolen 104 from human minds in the first world, 105 but if it lives under many suns,
106 tell me who you are and of what people; 107 do not be afraid to reveal to me 108 your ugly and loathsome punishment".
**Cornish:**
100 An mester da a'm oll ow tos, 101 ow leverel: "Dywedh dhynsi owth owth a vynsi"; 102 ha my a dhallathas, wosa ev henna:
103 "Mar nyns yw koffowgh henwynsi 104 yn kynsa bys a'n menowgh an dus, 105 mes mar yw byw a-woles howlow,
106 leverel pyw ywgh why ha a-bys pobel; 107 na vynsi bos ofen dhe weles dhym 108 an boen ha'n boen boenowgh koskwhyth".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 «Io fui d’Arezzo, e Albero da Siena», 110 rispuose l’un, «mi fé mettere al foco; 111 ma quel per ch’io mori’ qui non mi mena.
query.result:
**English:**
109 "I was from Arezzo, and Alberto da Siena", 110 replied one, "had me put to the stake; 111 but he for whom I died did not lead me here.
**Cornish:**
109 "My a veu a-dhyworth Arezzo, hag Albero a Siena", 110 a leveris unn, "a wrug dhym mos dhe'n tan; 111 mes henna rag a verwis my a-dhyworth na'm gorra dhym yma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Vero è ch’i’ dissi lui, parlando a gioco: 113 “I’ mi saprei levar per l’aere a volo”; 114 e quei, ch’avea vaghezza e senno poco,
115 volle ch’i’ li mostrassi l’arte; e solo 116 perch’ io nol feci Dedalo, mi fece 117 ardere a tal che l’avea per figliuolo.
query.result:
**English:**
112 It is true that I said to him, speaking in jest: 113 "I could lift myself into the air and fly"; 114 and he, who had little wisdom and desire,
115 wanted me to show him the art; and only 116 because I did not make him a Daedalus, he caused 117 me to be burned by one who considered him a son.
**Cornish:**
112 Gwir yw henna a leveris dhe, ow leverel yn jek: 113 "Yth allavow hedhes dhe'n ayr dhe hedhes"; 114 ha henna, a vea ytholl vyghan ha sens,
115 a vynna dhym dhe wosa dhodho an arta; ha unn sel 116 awos na wrugav Dedalo dhodho, ev a wrug 117 dhym dhe vos loskys gans unn a'n jeva dhodho avel mab.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Ma ne l’ultima bolgia de le diece 119 me per l’alchìmia che nel mondo usai 120 dannò Minòs, a cui fallar non lece».
query.result:
**English:**
118 But in the last bolgia of the ten 119 Minos, who cannot err, condemned me 120 for the alchemy that I practiced in the world.
**Cornish:**
118 Mes yn ughella bolgia a'n deg 119 My a veu gondemnys gans Minos, na alla bos mar, 120 rag an alkemi a wrugav y'n bys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 E io dissi al poeta: «Or fu già mai 122 gente sì vana come la sanese? 123 Certo non la francesca sì d’assai!».
query.result:
**English:**
121 And I said to the poet: "Was there ever 122 a people as vain as the Sienese? 123 Certainly not the French, by far!".
**Cornish:**
121 Ha my a leveris dhe'n bardh: "A veu bythkweth 122 pobel ken veur avel an Senesyon? 123 Sygur na veu an Frynkyon ken moy!".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Onde l’altro lebbroso, che m’intese, 125 rispuose al detto mio: «Tra’mene Stricca 126 che seppe far le temperate spese,
127 e Niccolò che la costuma ricca 128 del garofano prima discoverse 129 ne l’orto dove tal seme s’appicca;
130 e tra’ne la brigata in che disperse 131 Caccia d’Ascian la vigna e la gran fonda, 132 e l’Abbagliato suo senno proferse.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Whereupon the other leper, who heard me, 125 replied to my words: "Bring to my mind Stricca, 126 who knew how to spend his money wisely,
127 and Niccolò, who first discovered 128 the costly habit of the clove 129 in the garden where such a seed is planted;
130 and bring to my mind the company in which 131 Caccia d'Ascian squandered his vineyard and his great wealth, 132 and Abbagliato offered his wisdom.
**Cornish:**
124 Wosa henna, an leprys aral, a'm klevsis, 125 a leveris dhe'm ger: "Henwel dhym dhe gof Stricca, 126 a wydha bos mar dhe wul an arghans,
127 ha Niccolò, a dhiskudhas kynsa 128 an defodh kostus a'n garofano 129 yn arloedh le mayth omma seudh avel henna;
130 ha henwel dhym an gompani le mayth 131 Caccia d'Ascian a wrug gorfenna y winva ha'y vonedh meur, 132 ha Abbagliato a wrug proferi y sens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Ma perché sappi chi sì ti seconda 134 contra i Sanesi, aguzza ver’ me l’occhio, 135 sì che la faccia mia ben ti risponda:
136 sì vedrai ch’io son l’ombra di Capocchio, 137 che falsai li metalli con l’alchìmia; 138 e te dee ricordar, se ben t’adocchio,
139 com’ io fui di natura buona scimia».
query.result:
**English:**
133 But so that you may know who thus supports you 134 against the Sienese, fix your eyes on me, 135 so that my face may answer you well:
136 you will see that I am the shade of Capocchio, 137 who falsified metals with alchemy; 138 and you should remember, if I look at you closely,
139 how I was by nature a good ape.
**Cornish:**
133 Mes rag bos dhe wodhes pyw yw owth a'th skoedh 134 orth an Senesyon, skoodh dhym dhe'm lagha, 135 marow henna yth alla bos dhe weles dhym yn da:
136 yth weles bos henna owth yw kevriji Capocchio, 137 a wrug falsya an metlys gans alkemi; 138 ha dhodho a dhre dhe gof, mar owth owth owth ow kolwel,
139 hemma owth veu yn naturel simi da.
